turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: That's what he says. I got a man from headquarters checking up on it now.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Good.  You've got nothing to worry about. Soon as the report comes in, you'll be released.  And listen, don't talk so loud. Take it easy. Coast a little.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: All I know is the bank's been robbed and a murder's been committed. The way I see it, Brown here looks guilty.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What are you talking about? He had no more to do with it than you did.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Maybe. But I'm taking no chances.  Why, this kid's got a record.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: So have you. So have I. So's everybody got a record. What difference does that make? You can't go around pinning crimes on people just because theyÂ—

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Of course it's true - and he knows it.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Listen, Matt. If you don't tell the truth, I can't help you. Where were you last night?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: You were right, Mr. Dickson! Brown didn't have anything to do with it. Here's your man.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Why, you must be crazy. I've known this man for years.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: He's just confessed. He's been mixed up with the toughest gangsters in town.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: My wife? What's she got to do with you?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: No wonder he didn't want to mention her name.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You're lying!

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Don't worry, Mr. Dickson. We'll find out whether he's telling the truth. I'll have a man from headquarters check up on it right away.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You don't want to check up on anybody. I'll do all the checking up. Wait a minute.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Well, Sampson, what is it?

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Here's the data on the Clyde deal.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Good. I'll take this along with me. Tell Clyde I'll see him tomorrow. I'm sick and tired of the delay.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: I'm afraid he's been stalling.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: That's just exactly what he has been doing. This deal should have been closed weeks ago. Tell him to keep tomorrow open . . .

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: He says he can't get away in the daytime.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: How about his nights? He's too busy running around. Tell him to keep tomorrow night open, come in and sign this thing, or I'll call this whole deal off.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: The lobby's half filled now.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: They've been coming in steady all morning. I have called for some extra police.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: All right. Send down to the vaults and have our reserve cash sent up here right away.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: We haven't much on hand, you know. If it gets any worse, I hope we don't have to close the doors.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: The bank's reputation wouldn't be worth a nickel after that. This is just a flurry, that's all. They've heard about the robbery and got panic-stricken. Listen, get a hold of our available securities and have them turned into cash. Wait a minute. Get my personal stuff and have that turned into cash too. Tell the boys anyone caught arguing with a depositor will be fired on the spot.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Look at them, Mr. Dickson. They're going crazy.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Did you get the case for the securities?

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Mine too?

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Yes, sir. But soon as our money runs out, they'll mob the place.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: The fools! If they only knew it, they're making things worse for themselves. Somebody starts a silly rumor, and they lose their heads.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: What'll we do?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I'll talk to them. Listen, go back and tell the boys to stall as much as possible. Tell 'em not to pay any attention to what I said. Tell 'em to verify every signature.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: We can't keep open till four o'clock. We haven't cash enough to last an hour.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Don't you think I know it?

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Mr. Dickson! Mr. Dickson!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Get all the big bills in the place. Take them out and get them changed. Get nothing but ones and fives. Distribute them among the tellers. Tell them to take their time. Stall as much as possible. Count and recount the money.

turns.speaker: SAMPSON
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I hate to do this, but I've got to have time to dig up some help. I think I know where I can get some real cash. Snap into it, Sampson. We will lick this thing yet.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Yes, ma'am, you can deposit your money here.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: Is it safe?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Absolutely.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: It's his life insurance money, you know.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Quiet down, please! Take it easy, folks. Everything will be all right.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: But you said it would be safe! It's his life insurance money. Oh, please, I'll go to the Old Ladies' Home if you don't do something, please!

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Please, lady. Please be quiet. Everything will be all right.  Open up here, folks. All right, folks, please!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: How-do-you-do, Mrs. Dickson.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Is that busy husband of mine busy?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He's at a board meeting.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Board meeting. Oh, that means hours, I suppose.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I'm afraid so.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Helen, did you ever try competing with a bank?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Well, take my word for it, and don't try it. It's useless!  If it were some other woman, I could handle her, but after all, you can't scratch a bank's eyes out now, can you?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Hardly.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Oh, well. I guess the only other thing for me to do is to go out and buy myself a few sticks of dynamite. When he comes out, you tell him I'll be back. He hasn't gotten rid of me!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Hello, Helen!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Matt, come here!

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Come here, honey!

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Hey, look out, somebody's likely to see us!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh, is that so?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What did you do with it?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: With what?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: The ten dollars.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Oh, ten dollarsÂ—

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: A friend of mine - yeah, really - his mother was terribly sick and she was dying, would you believe it?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Oh, you think I'm lying?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: All right, I'm lying. Don't forget you called me a liar.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh, Matt.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Say, I just heard the merger isn't going thru. Isn't that grand?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Yeah, swell.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What happened? What did he say? Did you get the job?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What's the matter, Matt? Gee, I thought you'd be thrilled to death.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Come here.  You know, a few minutes ago I was in Cluett's office and Mrs. Dickson was there.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Well . . . ?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Well, he was making love to her.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh Matt, you must be mistaken.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I tell you, I saw them!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: In Cluett's office?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Yes, right in his office, the rat. I'd like to take a crack at that guy.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What's keeping you?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Oh, Charlie again.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Say Matt, you haven't done anything about what you saw today, have you?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Who? Cluett? No, not yet. But I'd like to take a crack at that stiff- necked, horse dollar.[6]

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh now, don't be silly.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Can you imagine that guy? He was kissing her.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Now you've got me worried, dear.  Promise me you won't butt in.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Okay, honey - but just the same I'd like to take a crack at thatÂ—

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Shh . . . !  I'll wait for you upstairs.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: All right, dear.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh, Matt . . .

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Don't cry, honey. Everything's gonna be all right.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: What's he doing, honey? Is he getting any help?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Something's happened. He isn't trying anymore.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: They must have turned him down.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes. He called some of the biggest people in town.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Sure, they'd turn him down. He ought to know that. I'm going in there and talk to him.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Did you talk to him?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Yeah.  I got an idea. Come on, let's get to a telephone.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Dickson's in a jam I tell you. The run's getting worse.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Mr. Williams . . .

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: The big guys have got the screws on him. You've got to come through for him, Mr. Conway. He came through for you a hundred times. If his friends don't help him, who is going to help him?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Matt, look! There's Mr. Jones!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Did you say Dude Finlay?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Yes, why?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He was in the bank yesterday.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: He was here?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He came to see Mr. Cluett.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What did you find out, Mike?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I've been trailing the cashier like you told me. You're right about that guy, chief. There's something screwy somewhere.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Never mind all that. What did you find out?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: He left here about an hour ago and went down to Dude Finlay's joint.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Dude Finlay?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Do you know this young man, Mrs. Halligan?

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: Sure I do. He has the best room in me house. The one with the fancy wallpaper.

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: Â—for the rheumatism, you know.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What time was it, Mrs. Halligan?

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: It was late, I know. The Dooley sisters was already in. They work at a show, you know.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What time was it?

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What time did Matt Brown get in?

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: Now, let me see - a half hour after the Dooley sisters - and the Dooley sisters never get home until afterÂ—

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: I don't care about the Dooley sisters - what time did he get in?

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: That's just what I'm trying to tell you, sir. It was a half hour after the Dooley sisters . . .

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Was it twelve o'clock?

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: Yes, I guess it was one, 'cause...

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: It couldn't have been earlier?

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: No. It wasn't earlier because...

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Yes, I know. Cause the Dooley sisters weren't in yet.

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: No - because me clock struck four, and when it strikes four, it's one.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: There you are!

turns.speaker: MRS. HALLIGAN
turns.text: Listen here, young man - nobody ever called me a liar yet and got away with itÂ—

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: That's all, Mrs. Halligan. Thanks.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: You turned off the burglar alarm, you set the time clock, came back at twelve and emptied the boxes, didn't you?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: wasn't anywhere near this placeÂ—

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Sit down! When the watchman surprised you, you shot him - what'd you do with the gun?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I didn't do it! I haven't got a gun!

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: You used to carry a gun, didn't you?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Then who changed it?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: So you were home last night?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What time did you get in?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Well, about - uh - eleven o'clock.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Eleven o'clock, eh? Are you sure it was that?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: But I wasn't here, Mr. Dickson. Honest I wasn't . . .

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Then where were you?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: You're carrying too much money on you, Hank. You better turn some in tonight.

turns.speaker: TELLER
turns.text: Okay, Matt.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: How are you fixed?

turns.speaker: TELLER
turns.text: I'm okay, Matt.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: You've got enough?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: That mug reminds me of a guy with his second dollar.

turns.speaker: TELLER
turns.text: Yeah, what did he do with his first one?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Bought himself a pocketbook!

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Everybody in?

turns.speaker: TELLER
turns.text: I guess so.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Where's Charlie?

turns.speaker: TELLER
turns.text: Charlie's upstairs as sore as a pup. He's out fourteen cents, and he can't find it.

turns.speaker: TELLER
turns.text: Certainly, Mr. Jones! Certainly! Charlie!

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: They're starting to come in already. Yeah. Yeah. Well, listen. Don't waste any time. Get all the money you can lay your hands on, and bring it down here right away. Step on it.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: You can ride like that?

turns.speaker: COMANCHE TOM
turns.text: I said like a Comanche, not this Comanche.

turns.speaker: COMANCHE TOM
turns.text: I think I may just go on to the reservation.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Tom, I'm this close to coming with you...

turns.speaker: COMANCHE TOM
turns.text: I couldn't lose him.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Jim Younger, I told you--

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: This is healing?

turns.speaker: COMANCHE TOM
turns.text: Sometimes a wound will kill.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Now you tell us.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Gatling! They've got a Gatling!

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Dammit, this stopped being fun about two years ago!

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: He's smiling.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Never a good thing.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Never thought that pissant town would look so pretty.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Anywhere nobody's shooting at me is pretty.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Your Ma wouldn't let us leave until we ate something.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: That was two hours ago.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Here's Liberty's favorite son!  I'll never forget what you did, cousin.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Zee, I'm pleased you came.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Our place, Clell Miller's, Sammy Johnston, the Creeders. Will Hite.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: The sheriff says it was a gang of drunk Kansas boys.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I say we ride into town and kill us some Pinkertons and railroad men.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: These are deeds and mortgages of farms the bank was holding for the railroad.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Better pass them over here before something happens to 'em.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Uhh, yeah it does.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: You stay out of this, Bob.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: No, Jimmy has a point. The Younger-James Gang could be confusing.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Say we bust into a bank. We yell "We're the Younger-James Gang!" People are gonna be thinking, "The younger James Gang? Is there an older James Gang? How come we never heard of the older James gang?" So people are trying to figure that out instead of raising their arms.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: We got a problem here, brother?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Frankly, yes. I'm feeling a little left out.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: That's what the newspapers say. Weren't for Jesse James, this gang wouldn't be able to find a goat's ass with a stick.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: This is the best score yet.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: It's still taking too long. The people used to snap to.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: That was because of... the reputation the gang had.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: As long as people think Jesse's still riding, we will never get the respect we deserve.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Cole, we're outlaws. Not exactly the most respectable job, if you know what I mean.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Leave me alone, Bob.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: How'd they --

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: What have you done?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I ain't done --

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: WHAT HAVE YOU DONE?!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Bob. I didn't...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Swear.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I swear --

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Swear on Jimmy's grave.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I'm sorry, Cole.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: You're just upset about Jesse. We all are.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Things changed when you quit the gang. For example, I'm now the one who says "Let's ride."

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: He's not bad at it.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: It's tougher than it looks.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: My plan of lying here pissing myself seems to be working mighty fine, thank you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I can hit those boys from here. We just need a distraction.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yesterday.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Well, somebody better go tell THE DAMN YANKEES!

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Corn gonna shoot at me?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Then I love it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Jesus mercy, that's Charlie Higgins, Dave Laller ...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: ... Will Perry ...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Cole, I want to get to the farm, make sure Little Jim and the girls are okay.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Stop by our spread after that, tell our Ma we're all right. We'll go to Doc Mimms.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: They came up, made the same offer they made you folks. Our little brother Jim tried to chase 'em off, one of those detectives hit him in the head, knocked him out. Cole lost his temper.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh no...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: He just lost his temper a little.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Damn!

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: They said because the detectives were working for the Department of the Interior --

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The Army can hang him.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Home. We go home. We ride like hell to get there, and we kill anything or anyone that comes between us and our homes. And when we get there we stay there and God help any fool who tries to get me to leave my farm again.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Best damn plan I heard all war.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: How many of them did he kill?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Two.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You have no shame.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Not yet. But I'm hoping.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: But if we take their money and supplies...

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: All right, settle down. All this money ain't ours.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Well, no, Jesse, it was the bank's. That's why we had to go to all that trouble of stealing it.  You explain it to him.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: We oughta take some of this, give it to our neighbors in Liberty. Lot of people hurting up there.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: "The outlaws calling themselves the James-Younger Gang shot their way out of town, wounding the Sherriff and three other townsfolk."

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: "Bank officials estimate the loss at fifty thousand dollars."

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Okay, folks, I think we know how this is going to go...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: One false move and I'll blow your heads off!

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Beg pardon?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: You heard me, Jesse. You know how crazy I get!

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: This is about the "Wanted!" Posters, isn't it.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Yes. I am obviously not standing out in people's minds at the robberies.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: The things a fella has to do to get a little respect around here...

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You are a fine figure of a man.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Listen, Jesse, we've got a problem.  It's Cole.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: He's been full of vinegar lately.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: He's planning a job.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Listen, he's my brother and I don't want to start trouble...

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: BURLY DETECTIVE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You, ya barrel of pork lard. Here piggy piggy!

turns.speaker: BURLY DETECTIVE
turns.text: What you sayin' boy?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I think I recognize you.

turns.speaker: BURLY DETECTIVE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I think I saw you leavin' by the front door just as I was coming in the back.

turns.speaker: BURLY DETECTIVE
turns.text: You shut up now, boy.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: No, really. You're wife said she needed some help, seeing as you were so fat you couldn't find your --

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: 'Bout time you got here, buddy.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Ride with me, cousin?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I could use the walk.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Suit yourself. We'll have some horses waiting for you at the road.  Let's ride, Rangers!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Where you boys going?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: There's Yankees back there. Lot's of 'em.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Home, boys. Back to our farms.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Planting corn. Harvesting corn. Year after year.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Hands off your hip, Cole.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: You're not scared, are you?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Pick your fights, cousin. You taught me that.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Not now.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: What is wrong with you?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: In case we have to kill these sonofabitches, I don't want them to see us coming.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You ever notice Zerelda's eyes?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: She got two of them.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: She had a moustache.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: She was European!

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: All right, calm down. I'll agree Sadie was a woman --

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Thanks for the help.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: After all you did on our farm?  You miss it, don't you Jesse?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: The war? What, are you crazy?  There are things I miss about it.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: It was exciting.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: But it was a whole lot of killing. Why should we miss that?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Because we were good at it?  Hell, we were great at it. Jesse, don't tell anyone I said this, because everybody knows I'm the toughest man in this town, but you are one terrifying sonofabitch with those guns.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Yeah.
